study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of an 8-week in-season elastic band training program on explosive muscle performance, change of direction, and repeated changes of direction in junior male handball players.
results_summary: The study found small to trivial improvements in peak power, 1RM strength, sprint times, change-of-direction, and repeated change-of-direction parameters, but no significant changes in vertical jump performance or limb muscle volumes. The elastic band training yielded measurable gains in performance metrics relevant to handball.
population_specificity: Junior male handball players (30 men, aged 18.7 ± 0.8 years).
effective_dosage: Biweekly lower-limb elastic band training (knee and hip extension).

study_goal: To analyze the effects of complex strength training on explosive muscle performance in junior female handball players.
results_summary: The intervention improved sprint performance, change-of-direction ability, and jumping metrics, but had no significant effect on repeated-sprint T-test or balance scores.
population_specificity: Junior female handball players (n=28, divided into experimental and control groups).
effective_dosage: Not specified (part of regular regimen replaced with complex strength training).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effect of physical activity intervention on the cardiorespiratory system of elite female handball players.
results_summary: The study found significant decreases in relative body fat and increases in relative muscle mass, along with notable improvements in ventilation, oxygen pulse, and both absolute and relative aerobic capacities. Individual changes in body composition and cardiorespiratory parameters were also highlighted.
population_specificity: 16 elite female handball players

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effect of high-intensity muscular strength and sprint interval training on lower limb explosive performance and anthropometric characteristics in elite male handball players.
results_summary: The study found significant improvements in all tested parameters (strength, speed, jumps, agility) in the training group, with large effect sizes (mean d = 1.85), while the control group showed no improvement or slight declines. The combined high-intensity training was concluded to enhance handball-related performance without compromising other aspects.
population_specificity: 22 male elite handball athletes aged 20.2 ± 0.1 years.
effective_dosage: 3-4 sets of 70-85% 1-RM dynamic back half squat, followed by 4-6 maximal intensity 30m sprints, twice weekly.

study_goal: To test the effectiveness of a video-overlay feedback method on landing technique in elite handball players.
results_summary: The video group showed improved knee and hip flexion at initial contact and peak flexion, increased range of motion, and better Landing Error Scoring System (LESS) scores. No differences were found in shot accuracy or vertical jump height, but horizontal jump distance increased in the video group.
population_specificity: 16 elite female handball players (8 in the video group, 8 in the control group).
effective_dosage: Not applicable (intervention was video feedback, not a supplement).
study_duration: Pretest, 2 training sessions, and posttest (exact duration not specified).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether an injury-prevention program could effectively reduce severe knee injuries in adolescent team handball players.
results_summary: The study found that the intervention group had significantly fewer severe knee injuries (0.04/1000 h) compared to the control group (0.33/1000 h), with an odds ratio of 0.11 (p=0.019). Other lower extremity injuries showed no significant difference between groups.
population_specificity: Adolescent handball players (mean age ~15 years, 279 participants across 23 teams).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether frequent, immediate, augmented feedback (knowledge of results) during training increases throwing velocity in handball set shots.
results_summary: Participants who received feedback on throwing velocity showed a significantly greater increase in velocity (8.1% vs. 2.7%) for normal ball throws compared to the control group. Similar but smaller effects were observed for heavy ball throws (5.1% vs. 2.5%). No gender differences in velocity change were found except for the experimental group using the normal ball.
population_specificity: 50 female and 73 male physical education students.
effective_dosage: Two series of ten set shots with maximal effort, twice a week.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether a shoulder-strengthening program could prevent shoulder pain in junior female handball players.
results_summary: The strength-training program did not prevent shoulder pain, with both intervention and control groups reporting low pain levels. The intervention group showed improved push-up performance but no other significant differences.
population_specificity: Junior female handball players (J 16) from top teams in Norway's Trøndelag region.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the acute physical and physiological demands of recreational team handball and assess its potential as an exercise mode for fitness and health enhancement in untrained men aged 33-55.
results_summary: The study found that recreational team handball is an intermittent high-intensity exercise, with participants covering 6012 ± 428 m per match, exercising at 81-90% HRmax for 47% of match time, and achieving blood lactate levels indicating significant anaerobic demand. The results suggest it could positively impact aerobic, anaerobic, and musculoskeletal fitness in adults.
population_specificity: Untrained men aged 33-55 years.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether a specific neuromuscular warm-up program could improve static and dynamic balance in female handball athletes, potentially reducing lower extremity injury risk.
results_summary: The intervention group showed significant improvements in center of pressure sway velocity and star excursion balance test scores compared to the control group, with measurable changes observed after six weeks of training.
population_specificity: Female handball athletes (24.0 ± 5.9 years).
effective_dosage: 15-minute warm-up program, three times per week.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of arthroscopic treatment for Sinding-Larsen-Johansson (SLJ) syndrome in a professional handball player.
results_summary: The study found that arthroscopic excision of the SLJ lesion led to complete symptom resolution and allowed the patient to return to competitive sports after 5 months, despite prior unsuccessful conservative treatments.
population_specificity: 29-year-old male professional handball player with SLJ syndrome.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of two high-intensity interval training (HIIT) protocols with different interval durations (short vs. long) on physical performance in handball players.
results_summary: Both HIIT protocols (short and long intervals) significantly improved peak running velocity (VIFT) and repeated sprint ability (RSA) in handball players, with no significant differences between the two methods. The short-interval protocol was suggested as the preferred method due to higher specificity.
population_specificity: Eighteen highly-trained handball players (age: 22.7 ± 3.9 years; height: 181.5 ± 6.6 cm; body mass: 84.7 ± 14.1 kg).
effective_dosage: Short-interval (SI) group: 2 sets of 22 intervals of 10-second runs at 95% VIFT; long-interval (LI) group: 5 sets of 3-minute intervals at 85% VIFT, performed twice weekly.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effect of an exercise program (OSTRC Shoulder Injury Prevention Programme) on reducing the prevalence of shoulder problems in elite handball players.
results_summary: The intervention group showed a 6% lower average prevalence of shoulder problems (17% vs. 23%) and a 3% lower prevalence of substantial shoulder problems (5% vs. 8%) compared to the control group, with a 28% lower risk of shoulder problems overall.
population_specificity: Elite handball players (660 players from 45 teams, including 22 female and 23 male teams).
effective_dosage: The exercise program was delivered 3 times per week as part of the warm-up.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether a 6-week strength training program (STP) using elastic bands could improve shoulder muscle performance and ball-throwing speed in young female handball players.
results_summary: The STP significantly improved internal-rotator muscle power and ball-throwing speed in standing and jumping throws, but did not affect peak torque or shoulder-rotator muscle balance.
population_specificity: 39 young female handball players (ages 14.2–16.4 years).
effective_dosage: Not specified (progressive elastic-band exercises before regular training).

study_goal: To compare the effects of unknown vs known loads in strength training on power output and throwing velocity in junior handball players.
results_summary: Both groups improved similarly in 1RM bench press and power output, but the unknown loads group showed greater gains in early power intervals and throwing velocity.
population_specificity: Junior team-handball players (17.2 ± 0.6 years, 1.79 ± 0.07 m, 75.6 ± 9.4 kg).
effective_dosage: Two sessions weekly, four sets of six repetitions of bench press throw at 30%, 50%, and 70% of 1RM.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effectiveness of reactive jump training in improving jump height and power development among handball players.
results_summary: Reactive jump training significantly improved jump height but did not show significant differences in power development compared to the control group. Correlations were found between muscle activity and performance metrics, suggesting potential for further research in rehabilitation and injury prevention.
population_specificity: 21 regional league handball players (intervention group: n=12, control group: n=9).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of small-sided games (SSGs) and repeated shuffle sprint (RSS) training on repeated sprint ability (RSA) and countermovement jump (CMJ) performance in elite handball players.
results_summary: Both SSG and RSS training significantly improved all assessed performance variables, with RSS showing greater improvements in 10-m sprint, CMJ, and jump shot, while SSG was more effective for agility and standing throw. The study concluded that both methods are effective for fitness development in elite handball players.
population_specificity: Eighteen highly trained elite adult handball players (24.8 ± 4.4 years).
effective_dosage: SSG: 5 small-sided games (3-a-side) twice a week; RSS: 2 sets of 14-17 shuttle sprints (20-m) and 9-m jump shots with 20-second recoveries twice a week.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of global postural reeducation in improving spinopelvic alignment in a young handball player with low-grade isthmic spondylolisthesis.
results_summary: The intervention significantly reduced lumbar lordosis, sacral slope, and anterior pelvic tilting by 17.2°, 16.5°, and 15.1°, respectively, demonstrating effectiveness in correcting spinopelvic misalignment. Global postural reeducation was concluded as a viable nonsurgical treatment option for this condition.
population_specificity: 15-year-old male handball player with low-grade isthmic spondylolisthesis and spinopelvic misalignment.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether handball training improves cognitive ability in elderly individuals with mild cognitive impairment.
results_summary: The study found that handball training significantly increased MMSE scores (indicating improved cognitive function) and decreased ADL scores (suggesting better daily living abilities) after 3 and 6 months, with no significant changes observed in the control group.
population_specificity: Elderly individuals with mild cognitive impairment (n=60, divided into training and control groups).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of chokeberry supplementation on performance and exercise-induced biomarkers in athletes, including handball players.
results_summary: Chokeberry supplementation may enhance redox balance in athletes, but evidence is insufficient to conclusively determine its effects on inflammation, platelet function, iron metabolism, and exercise performance.
population_specificity: Athletes (including handball players, rowers, football players, triathletes, and runners)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether circadian rhythms influence sports performance after creatine supplementation in handball players.
results_summary: After twelve weeks, participants showed decreased fat percentage, increased body weight and body water, and improved performance, with no significant differences between morning and evening supplementation groups.
population_specificity: Fourteen women players of a handball team.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine the effects of multiday beetroot juice ingestion on neuromuscular performance in semi-professional, male handball players.
results_summary: Beetroot juice significantly improved countermovement jump (4.7%) and isometric handgrip strength (7.8%) compared to placebo, but no significant differences were found for other neuromuscular performance variables. The only side effect was red urine production, which was more prevalent with beetroot juice.
population_specificity: Semi-professional, male handball players competing in the second Spanish national division.
effective_dosage: 70 ml of beetroot juice (6.4 mmol nitrate) or placebo (0.04 mmol nitrate) daily for three consecutive days.
study_duration: Three days per condition with a 1-week washout between conditions.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether the effectiveness of handwashing interventions on reducing diarrhea risk varies by season in low- and middle-income countries.
results_summary: Handwashing interventions showed a stronger effect in reducing diarrhea risk during dry seasons (33% reduction) compared to rainy seasons (18% reduction). The study highlights the need for seasonally robust interventions to account for climate variations.
population_specificity: Low- and middle-income countries

study_goal: The researchers aimed to identify predictors of handwashing with water and soap at critical times among mothers/caregivers of children under-5 years in rural Afghanistan.
results_summary: Access to handwashing facilities with water and soap, treatment at public facilities, having children under 2 years, and recent infectious diseases were significant predictors of improved handwashing behavior. The study found higher odds of handwashing at critical times when these factors were present.
population_specificity: Mothers/caregivers of children under-5 years in rural Afghanistan.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess whether water, sanitation, and handwashing (WSH) interventions, alone or combined with nutrition interventions, could reduce antibiotic use in young children.
results_summary: In Bangladesh, handwashing (as part of WSH interventions) reduced caregiver-reported antibiotic use by 10-14% and multiple antibiotic uses by 26-35%, with greater effects in younger children. No significant effect was observed in Kenya.
population_specificity: Birth cohorts aged 3-28 months in Bangladesh and Kenya.
study_duration: Longitudinal measurement at three timepoints (exact duration not specified)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the prevalence of hand hygiene practices and evaluate the impact of hygiene interventions on bacterial load among orphaned children.
results_summary: The study found that bacterial contamination (Staphylococcus aureus and Escherichia coli) was significantly reduced after the intervention, with improvements in hand hygiene practices and accessibility to hygiene resources.
population_specificity: Orphaned children registered at the Save Our Souls children's orphanage school in Pakistan.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess changes in handwashing behaviors among residents before and during the COVID-19 pandemic in Ghana.
results_summary: Handwashing behaviors improved during the pandemic, with increased handwashing frequency (4-6 times/day), higher ownership of handwashing facilities, and greater odds of handwashing after sneezing. Television was the main source of handwashing training.
population_specificity: Residents aged 18-60 years from the Kintampo Health and Demographic Surveillance System (HDSS) in Ghana.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the effects of an integrated intervention including handwashing on physiological stress response, oxidative stress, and DNA methylation in young children.
results_summary: The combined nutrition, water, sanitation, and handwashing (N+WSH) intervention reduced oxidative stress markers, elevated post-stressor cortisol levels, and decreased methylation of the NGFI-A binding site, indicating enhanced adaptive stress responses in early childhood.
population_specificity: Rural Bangladeshi children aged 1-2 years.
effective_dosage: Not specified (handwashing with soap as part of a broader intervention).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of the PICHA7 program in increasing handwashing with a cleansing agent among diarrhea patients and their attendants in healthcare facilities in the DRC.
results_summary: The PICHA7 intervention significantly increased handwashing with a cleansing agent at key events (40% vs. 15% in the standard arm), demonstrating its effectiveness in promoting hygiene practices among high-risk populations. The odds ratio of 5.04 indicated a strong positive effect.
population_specificity: Diarrhea patients and their attendants in 27 healthcare facilities in urban Bukavu, South Kivu Province, DRC.
effective_dosage: Provision of a soapy water bottle (water and detergent powder) and a pictorial module on handwashing.
study_duration: The intervention was delivered at the bedside, with follow-up observations conducted within 24 hours. The overall study duration was from March 2020 to November 2021.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether temperature and precipitation modified the effect of handwashing and other WASH interventions on child diarrhea.
results_summary: Handwashing and other WASH interventions were most effective in preventing diarrhea during monsoon season, particularly after heavy rain or high temperatures, with significant protective effects observed under these conditions. The effectiveness varied by weather, showing stronger protection during rainy periods compared to dry or cooler conditions.
population_specificity: Children in rural Bangladesh.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the feasibility and effectiveness of the Wash'Em process in designing context-specific hygiene programs to improve handwashing behavior in crisis-affected populations.
results_summary: Despite incomplete implementation of the Wash'Em process due to logistical and budgetary constraints, the intervention was deemed feasible by implementers and was perceived as less top-down than traditional approaches. Exposed populations found the activities engaging, understood the content, and reportedly improved their handwashing behavior.
population_specificity: Drought-affected communities in Midland province, Zimbabwe.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate whether a hand hygiene intervention (training in hand-washing combined with an alcohol-based hand rub) reduces injection-related abscesses in people who inject drugs (PWID).
results_summary: The study proposes a randomized controlled trial to assess the intervention's effectiveness in reducing abscess prevalence, but results are not yet available as the trial is not yet recruiting.
population_specificity: People who inject drugs (PWID) in France.
effective_dosage: Not specified (single-use alcohol-based hand rub provided).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the impact of culturally relevant educational resources and workshops on improving handwashing practices and reducing childhood illnesses in Gujarat, India.
results_summary: The study found that the resources were used in over 200 schools, with 92.28% of teachers planning to use them in classrooms and 58.16% of children showing improved understanding of handwashing. Teachers reported reduced vomiting and diarrhoeal illnesses in 46 schools after using the resources.
population_specificity: Children and teachers in Gujarat, India.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the impact of chlorinated water delivery (as part of a WASH intervention) on gut microbiota profiles in household-contact children of cholera patients.
results_summary: The intervention led to a significant reduction in pathogenic Proteobacteria (including Vibrionaceae) and an increase in beneficial Firmicutes in the gut microbiota of children, suggesting potential for cholera prevention and improved child health.
population_specificity: Household-contact children of cholera patients in Dhaka city slums.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate changes in handwashing knowledge and practices among beneficiaries of the Suchana intervention in rural Bangladesh.
results_summary: The Suchana intervention significantly improved handwashing knowledge and practices, with higher odds of correct handwashing behaviors in the intervention area compared to the control. The study suggests scaling up similar interventions for vulnerable rural populations.
population_specificity: Rural residents, particularly mothers and children, in the Sylhet region of Bangladesh.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effectiveness of the 'Surprise Soap' intervention versus a standard health messaging and plain soap intervention in increasing handwashing with soap among older children in a refugee settlement.
results_summary: The study found no significant difference in handwashing with soap between the 'Surprise Soap' and standard intervention groups at any follow-up point (4, 12, or 16 weeks). Both interventions showed a similar increase in handwashing behavior initially, which was sustained over 16 weeks.
population_specificity: Children aged 5-12 in a refugee settlement in Sudan.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the association between household environmental factors and handwashing practices with essential agents in sub-Saharan Africa.
results_summary: Only 34.84% of households practiced handwashing with essential agents, with significant variations between countries. Factors like education, household wealth, and access to handwashing facilities were positively associated with handwashing, while rural residence and lack of water access were negatively associated.
population_specificity: Households in sub-Saharan Africa (203,311 households across 18 countries).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to estimate the effect of interventions promoting handwashing with soap on acute respiratory infections (ARI) in low-income and middle-income countries (LMICs).
results_summary: Interventions promoting handwashing with soap reduced any ARI (RR 0.83), lower respiratory infections (RR 0.78), and upper respiratory infections (RR 0.74), but did not significantly affect test-confirmed influenza, COVID-19, or all-cause mortality.
population_specificity: Participants of any age in domestic, school, or childcare settings in LMICs.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of handwashing and gargling education on preventing respiratory tract infections (RTIs) in Japanese children.
results_summary: Handwashing and gargling education were associated with reduced influenza at age 4.5 but showed no preventive effects on airway infections at ages 4.5 and 9, influenza at age 9, or hospitalizations. The preventive effect was stronger in low-income households.
population_specificity: 38,554 children born in 2010 in Japan, surveyed at ages 3.5, 4.5, and 9 years.
study_duration: 12-month observation period before the survey at age 3.5, with follow-up at ages 4.5 and 9.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to identify barriers and facilitators to community handwashing with water and soap (HWWS) globally to improve infection control and prevention.
results_summary: The study identified 21 barriers and 23 facilitators to HWWS, organized into the Theoretical Domains Framework, with key themes including resource availability, cost, infrastructure, and knowledge. The findings can inform interventions to improve HWWS rates.
population_specificity: Community populations across 26 countries, with frequent representation from Bangladesh, India, and Kenya.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effect of magnesium supplementation on plasma and erythrocyte concentrations of magnesium and zinc, and their relationship with training load in high-performance handball players.
results_summary: Magnesium supplementation significantly increased plasma magnesium levels during the supplemented period, which persisted afterward. Erythrocyte magnesium and zinc levels showed associations with training volume at different intensities, and magnesium levels were linked to training volume post-supplementation.
population_specificity: 14 high-performance handball players
study_duration: Two months of supplementation followed by two months without supplementation

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether the "Surprise Soap" intervention was more effective than a standard handwashing intervention in increasing handwashing with soap among children in a humanitarian setting.
results_summary: Both the Surprise Soap and standard interventions significantly increased handwashing with soap, but there was no evidence of a difference in effectiveness between the two approaches at 4, 12, or 16 weeks post-intervention.
population_specificity: Children aged 5-12 in internally displaced persons (IDP) camps in Kahda district, Somalia.
effective_dosage: Not specified (intervention included soap with embedded toys or plain soap, delivered via household sessions).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore NGO practitioners' perspectives on the challenges and solutions for effective handwashing with soap (HWWS) interventions targeting older children (aged 5-14 years).
results_summary: The study identified 12 key challenges to HWWS interventions, including lack of prioritization, funding inconsistency, and unengaging content, and recommended solutions at intervention, organizational, and sector levels. Contextual factors like resource availability and coordination were highlighted as critical for success.
population_specificity: Older children (aged 5-14 years) in development and humanitarian settings.
study_duration: Interviews conducted from April to November 2020 (intervention duration not specified).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the relationship between responses to a mobile health program (CHoBI7) promoting handwashing with soap and its impact on diarrhea prevalence and WASH behaviors.
results_summary: Households that correctly responded to CHoBI7 IVR quiz messages had significantly lower odds of diarrhea and higher odds of proper handwashing with soap and improved stored water quality compared to those who did not answer the calls.
population_specificity: 517 households with 1,777 participants in Bangladesh.
effective_dosage: Not specified (intervention involved 14 IVR quiz messages on handwashing and water treatment).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the feasibility and acceptability of a combined hardware (Oxfam Handwashing Station) and software (Mum's Magic Hands) intervention to facilitate handwashing behavior in displacement camps and surrounding communities during the COVID-19 pandemic.
results_summary: The intervention was viewed as novel and appealing, though the handwashing station's design could be improved. The hygiene promotion package's implementation varied by country, and greater community engagement was recommended to address barriers and misconceptions.
population_specificity: Crisis-affected populations in displacement camps and surrounding communities in Bangladesh, Ethiopia, and the Democratic Republic of Congo.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to optimize a downward roughing filter unit for removing turbidity and suspended solids from handwashing wastewater.
results_summary: The study found optimal conditions (0.6 mm particle size, 12 cm filter depth, 0.3 Lmin-1 flow rate) achieved 62% turbidity and 67% TSS removal, with validation showing 55% and 53% removal, respectively. Additional removal efficiencies were 56% (apparent color), 20% (true color), 32% (BOD5), and 5% (COD).
population_specificity: Handwashing wastewater

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the association between access to handwashing facilities and the remaining need for trachoma intervention, hypothesizing that poor water/sanitation infrastructure correlates with trachoma burden.
results_summary: The study found that while simple regression models showed insignificant correlations, multivariable regression models incorporating access to handwashing facilities and population density were significant, indicating a link between poor water/sanitation infrastructure and trachoma burden.
population_specificity: 194 countries, with a focus on the South Pacific region where the top 5 countries with the greatest population proportion requiring trachoma intervention are located.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of a gamified live feedback intervention in improving hand hygiene behavior among preschool children in early childhood education and care settings.
results_summary: The study protocol outlines a four-arm cluster randomized controlled trial to assess hand hygiene behavior, self-efficacy, and intrinsic motivation, with outcomes measured at baseline, intervention, post-intervention, and a 12-month follow-up. The findings will determine whether the gamified live feedback intervention can be recommended for educational settings to promote better hand hygiene in preschool children.
population_specificity: Preschool children in early childhood education and care settings.
study_duration: Intervention phase duration not specified, but includes a 12-month follow-up.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the role of power dynamics in participatory approaches to handwashing interventions in Sierra Leone.
results_summary: The study found that participatory approaches increased community-led handwashing activities and engagement, regardless of leadership structures, while nonparticipatory approaches were influenced by distinct leadership dynamics. Strategic inclusion of community leaders was essential for project success and empowering individuals to practice handwashing.
population_specificity: Rural communities in Sierra Leone, including macro-level (political institutions), meso-level (community leaders and groups), and micro-level (families) actors.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the impact of a food safety training program with or without a realistic-event video on handwashing behavior modification among school nutrition employees.
results_summary: Handwashing practices were mostly in compliance (51.3% to 80.6%) for both groups across all phases. The experimental group showed higher behavioral intention for proper handwashing, but no statistical effect of the video intervention was found between groups.
population_specificity: 443 school nutrition employees responsible for food preparation and service across 21 school districts in 18 U.S. states.
study_duration: Data collected during 2017 (exact duration not specified)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate elementary schoolchildren's handwashing practices at two critical moments (before eating and after using the toilet) and identify associated factors.
results_summary: Only 50.1% of schoolchildren practiced handwashing at both critical moments, with factors like female gender, number of siblings, and availability of handwashing amenities influencing the practice. Only 34% used soap, with lack of soap and sinks being major barriers.
population_specificity: Fifth-grade schoolchildren in public secondary schools in Ulaanbaatar, Mongolia.
study_duration: Data collected between February and March 2019 (cross-sectional study, no intervention duration specified).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of a school WaSH intervention, including handwashing, on children's health outcomes such as malnutrition, dehydration, health literacy, and handwashing practices.
results_summary: Medium- and high-intensity health education interventions increased observed handwashing after using the toilet/urinal, with adjusted odds ratios of 3.18 and 3.89, respectively. The study found no improvement in overall health literacy scores but noted reductions in severe dehydration and overnutrition with higher-intensity interventions.
population_specificity: Children in grades 5, 6, 7, and 10 from 15 schools in Metro Manila, Philippines.
effective_dosage: Not specified (intervention included health education, WaSH policy workshops, hygiene supplies, and facility repairs).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether micro architectural interventions could promote handwashing compliance (HWC) among adolescents by creating an active environment.
results_summary: The study found that combined architectural interventions positively increased handwashing rates among adolescents, with higher satisfaction correlating to better compliance. However, rates declined sharply in colder months, reducing between-group differences.
population_specificity: Adolescents in a school setting in China post-COVID-19 pandemic closure.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effect of correct handwashing and mask-wearing training on COVID-19 fear and generalized anxiety in cardiac patients.
results_summary: The training significantly improved correct handwashing and mask-wearing techniques and reduced COVID-19 fear and anxiety in cardiac patients.
population_specificity: Cardiac patients in a tertiary hospital in western Turkey.
study_duration: Training and follow-up occurred over approximately one month.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of handwashing with soap in reducing childhood diarrhoea in low-income and middle-income countries (LMICs).
results_summary: Promotion of handwashing with soap reduced diarrhoea risk by 30% (RR 0.70 [0.64-0.76]), demonstrating significant efficacy in preventing childhood diarrhoea. The study supports the role of handwashing as an effective WASH intervention in LMICs.
population_specificity: Children in low-income and middle-income countries (LMICs).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the influence of parental engagement activities on improving WASH infrastructure and hygiene practices at home, particularly handwashing, within a school-based de-worming program.
results_summary: The intervention improved parents' knowledge and motivation for handwashing and sanitation, leading to infrastructure improvements (e.g., new latrines and handwashing facilities). However, long-term maintenance of handwashing stations with soap and water was limited.
population_specificity: Parents/guardians of children in a school-based de-worming program.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of handwashing with water and wood ash versus water alone in reducing faecal contamination of hands.
results_summary: Handwashing with wood ash significantly reduced E. coli counts compared to water alone, but two-thirds of samples still tested positive for E. coli after washing with wood ash. The study concluded that wood ash is better than water alone but less effective than soap.
population_specificity: Mothers and caregivers of children under 5 years in rural households of East Dembiya District, Ethiopia.
effective_dosage: One closed palm of wood ash per handwashing session.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the spatial distribution and determinant factors of handwashing practice using essential agents (soap and water) among households in Ethiopia.
results_summary: The study found spatial variation in handwashing practices, with the Amhara and Somali regions identified as significant hotspots with low handwashing rates. Households with low access to improved sanitation, low wealth, and low education were highlighted as priority targets for intervention.
population_specificity: Households in Ethiopia

study_goal: The researchers aimed to measure the effectiveness of handwashing at Dilla University referral hospital by assessing bacterial load reduction before and after handwashing.
results_summary: The study found that handwashing was 82.5% effective, with a 94.6% reduction in bacterial load (CFU/ml). Water usage and hand rubbing duration significantly influenced effectiveness.
population_specificity: Healthcare workers and participants at Dilla University Referral Hospital.
effective_dosage: Not specified (handwashing with an average of 336.03 ml water).
study_duration: Not specified (single session before and after handwashing).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to understand how the 2017 cholera outbreak in the Democratic Republic of the Congo influenced handwashing behavior and the determinants affecting hygiene practices.
results_summary: Handwashing with soap remained rare during the outbreak despite self-reported increases in behavior. Competing challenges like food scarcity and livelihood struggles hindered prioritization of handwashing, and environmental/social cues were lacking to make it convenient or desirable.
population_specificity: Residents of cholera-affected neighborhoods in the Democratic Republic of the Congo, including both case households (with cholera) and comparison households (without cholera).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effectiveness of combined water sanitation and hygiene (WASH) interventions versus individual interventions (water treatment or handwashing) in reducing diarrhea among under-five children in rural Dire Dawa.
results_summary: The study found a 41% reduction in diarrhea incidence with handwashing alone, comparable to the combined intervention. No additional benefit was observed from combining handwashing with water treatment.
population_specificity: Under-five children in rural Dire Dawa, Ethiopia.
effective_dosage: Not specified (soap provided, but exact usage frequency not detailed).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether a touchless dispenser system linked to automatic ICU doors could improve hand hygiene compliance among hospital staff and visitors.
results_summary: Hand hygiene performance significantly increased from 46.9% before the intervention to 98.5% after implementing the touchless dispenser system, demonstrating a strong improvement in compliance. The study suggests that linking hand sanitizer use to automatic door operation can effectively enhance infection control measures.
population_specificity: Hospital staff and visitors entering a paediatric ICU.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether a behavior change communication program could improve handwashing practices among tea supply chain workers in India.
results_summary: The study found a significant increase in the mean number of handwashing moments in 2 of the 4 worker groups, indicating partial success in improving hygiene behaviors. However, the improvements were not uniform across all groups.
population_specificity: Tea supply chain workers (estate workers, small holder farmers, and farm workers) in Tamil Nadu and Assam, India.
effective_dosage: Weekly 1-hour group sessions on handwashing for 4 weeks.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to improve handwashing duration to meet the recommended ≥20 seconds and assess the effect of washer fatigue with an intervention involving smart connected soap and towel dispensers synchronized to video content.
results_summary: The intervention increased mean handwashing duration by 7.5 seconds and improved compliance with the ≥20-second recommendation by 39.3%. The video content's effect peaked in month 1 and declined to a new steady state by month 11.
population_specificity: Not specified (likely general hand-washers in a healthcare or community setting).
effective_dosage: Not specified (intervention involved video engagement during handwashing).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the association between handwashing behavior and the incidence of diarrhea and respiratory infections in school-aged children in a low-income community in India.
results_summary: Handwashing at critical time-points reduced the odds of diarrhea by over 70% and respiratory infections by over 56%. Using a clean cloth after handwashing further lowered the odds of both conditions.
population_specificity: Schoolchildren aged 8-12 years and their mothers from six schools in a low-income community in New Delhi, India.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the acceptability, feasibility, and sustainability of a low-cost handwashing intervention among elementary schoolchildren in Bangladesh to improve hygiene practices.
results_summary: The intervention significantly increased handwashing with soapy water after 4 weeks (45% before eating, 83% after toileting, 100% after cleaning toilets), though adherence declined after 14 months (9.4% before eating, 37% after toileting). The intervention was found acceptable, feasible, and affordable for schools.
population_specificity: Elementary schoolchildren in Bangladesh.
effective_dosage: Soapy water solution (30 gm detergent with 1.5 L water) provided at handwashing stations.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the impact of behavioral economics "nudges" on increasing handwashing with soap (HWWS) among school-aged children in the Philippines.
results_summary: The intervention increased HWWS rates by 17.3 percentage points and improved access to functioning handwashing facilities with soap by 36%. The effects were consistent across gender and age groups.
population_specificity: Grades 1-6 students in 132 schools in the Philippines.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the effectiveness of ash as an alternative to soap in reducing microbial contamination of hands in rural settings.
results_summary: The study design involves comparing handwashing with water only and with ash, but results are not yet available as the abstract describes a planned trial.
population_specificity: Mothers or caregivers of under-5 children in rural northwest Ethiopia.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effect of three handwashing interventions (a social norm-based intervention, handwashing stations only, and no intervention) on handwashing with soap after toilet use.
results_summary: The social norm-based intervention combined with disgust-inducing messages and handwashing stations significantly increased handwashing with soap after toilet use (24% vs. 5% in controls at 1 month), with sustained effects. Handwashing stations alone had a modest effect (9% vs. 5% in controls).
population_specificity: Children and adults in communal housing compounds in Abidjan, Côte d'Ivoire.
study_duration: Follow-up assessments at 1 month and 5 months.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the functionality, social acceptability, and sustainability of the Autarky handwashing station in improving access to safe handwashing facilities in an informal settlement.
results_summary: The Autarky handwashing station demonstrated high functionality and social acceptability, aligning with WASH principles. Its novel design, reliability, and water-saving features increased community acceptance, though real-time monitoring feasibility requires further work.
population_specificity: Informal settlement residents in Durban, South Africa.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the multi-level determinants of handwashing behavior, focusing on socioecological and intersectional factors influencing its practice in low-income settings.
results_summary: The study identified social and structural barriers as highly relevant to handwashing practice, with intersecting social identities (e.g., age, gender, rural/urban location) creating inequities in the ability to perform handwashing. It highlighted how local leaders could influence structural determinants, while marginalized individuals (e.g., young rural wives) faced multiple constraints despite high intentions.
population_specificity: Experts in health promotion (n=22) and local citizens stratified by gender and rural/urban location (n=56) in Sierra Leone.
study_duration: Data collected between November 2018 and January 2019 (exact intervention duration not specified).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the underlying mechanism of change of the CHoBI7-mHealth program on handwashing with soap and stored drinking water quality.
results_summary: The CHoBI7-mHealth program significantly reduced diarrheal disease and stunting, increased handwashing with soap, and improved stored drinking water quality over 12 months. Psychosocial factors like self-efficacy and response efficacy mediated these effects.
population_specificity: Household members of diarrhea patients in Bangladesh.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the effect of modified hygiene kits (liquid soap, scented soap bar, and inclusion of a mirror) on handwashing behaviors among internally displaced persons in Moyale, Ethiopia.
results_summary: Handwashing with soap was rare at critical times across all study arms, with no significant increase in prevalence following the distribution of modified hygiene kits. Participants preferred liquid soap, scented soap bar, and the mirror, but these preferences did not translate into improved handwashing behavior.
population_specificity: Internally displaced persons in Moyale, Ethiopia, living in resource-poor, informal settlements.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate barriers to hand-washing adherence and assess the impact of an mHealth intervention on hand hygiene and bacterial contamination in medical residents.
results_summary: The intervention reduced Staphylococcus aureus contamination on hands significantly at 2 months, but the benefit was lost after discontinuation. No significant changes were observed for Escherichia coli and Klebsiella sp. Bacterial colonization on cell phones showed a tendency to decrease post-intervention.
population_specificity: Medical residents
effective_dosage: SMS reminders three times a week

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the efficiency of handwashing with soap in reducing diarrheal disease in children under 5 years old in rural kebeles of Dire Dawa, Ethiopia.
results_summary: The study found a significant reduction in diarrheal incidence in the handwashing intervention group (6.9 episodes per 100 person-weeks) compared to the control group (13.8 episodes per 100 person-weeks), resulting in a 41% reduction in diarrheal incidence. Handwashing with soap complemented with hand hygiene promotion was effective in decreasing diarrheal episodes.
population_specificity: Children under 5 years old in rural kebeles of Dire Dawa, Ethiopia.
effective_dosage: Two bars of plain soap provided bi-monthly.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effectiveness and uptake of a digital handwashing intervention (Germ Defence) in a controlled trial versus open dissemination, focusing on handwashing intentions and respiratory infection prevention.
results_summary: The study found that both the RCT and Germ Defence users increased handwashing intentions in 5 out of 7 situations, with significant mean differences. Germ Defence showed lower attrition during enrollment but lower completion rates for the core intervention compared to the RCT.
population_specificity: General public (Germ Defence) and participants recruited offline from general practices (RCT).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the efficacy of four school-based WaSH interventions (including handwashing) for improving children's health literacy, handwashing prevalence, and nutrition in LMICs.
results_summary: The study protocol outlines a comparison of interventions but does not provide specific results on handwashing effects; it focuses on measuring pre- and post-intervention outcomes like handwashing prevalence and health literacy.
population_specificity: School children in low- and middle-income countries (LMICs).
effective_dosage: Not specified (interventions included policy reinforcement, health education, hygiene supplies, and facility improvements).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the availability of handwashing amenities in public toilets during the COVID-19 pandemic and compare it to pre-pandemic data.
results_summary: The study found deficiencies in handwashing amenities, with 2.5% lacking water and 14.8% lacking soap. Improvements in soap provision were noted compared to pre-pandemic data, but overall handwashing infrastructure remained inadequate.
population_specificity: Public toilet facilities in New Zealand (400 surveyed).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the effects of hand-washing promotion interventions on diarrhoeal episodes in children and adults, particularly in low- and middle-income countries (LMICs) and high-income settings.
results_summary: Hand-washing promotion reduced diarrhoea episodes by about 30% in child day-care centres in high-income countries and among communities in LMICs, with moderate- to high-certainty evidence. Soap provision alongside education enhanced effectiveness, but long-term impacts and effects on diarrhoea-related deaths were not evaluated.
population_specificity: Children and adults in child day-care centres, schools, communities (primarily in LMICs), and a hospital-based high-risk population (people with AIDS).
effective_dosage: Not specified (education activities, sometimes with provision of soap).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the impact of removing supply and demand constraints on the uptake of handwashing and sanitation behaviors across wealth and education levels.
results_summary: The study found that the poorest households showed the greatest improvements in hand cleanliness, presence of water and soap in handwashing stations, and reductions in visible feces, indicating substantial overall improvements in equity. The intervention led to significant behavioral changes, particularly among the poorest participants.
population_specificity: Households in Bangladesh, stratified by wealth quintiles (Q1-Q5).
effective_dosage: Not specified (intervention included free WASH hardware and behavior change promotion).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the impact of educational resources (A Germ's Journey) on improving handwashing practices and germ understanding in young children.
results_summary: The multicomponent intervention (Study 1) significantly improved both handwashing behaviors and knowledge of germs, while the song intervention (Study 2) significantly improved handwashing behaviors compared to controls.
population_specificity: Young children (recruited from schools and a museum).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the impact of the HiFive program, a handwashing campaign targeting social and emotional motivators, on improving handwashing behavior among primary school students in the Philippines.
results_summary: The HiFive program led to a 3.7 percentage point increase in handwashing with soap and water and a 5.6 percentage point increase in handwashing with at least water after toilet use, along with a 10.8 percentage point increase in soap availability at handwashing facilities. However, the program had limited impact on the targeted motivators, suggesting improvements may have been driven by increased soap availability rather than behavioral changes.
population_specificity: Primary school students in two districts in the Philippines.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether a school-based hygiene program, including group handwashing activities, could foster independent handwashing and toothbrushing habits among Filipino children.
results_summary: The study found no significant difference in handwashing or toothbrushing behaviors between intervention and control schools after four months. Soap use and plaque reduction were similar in both groups, suggesting the program did not notably increase independent hygiene practices.
population_specificity: Filipino primary school children

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether handwashing and detergent treatment could reduce SARS-CoV-2 viral load on Halloween candy handled by COVID-19 patients.
results_summary: Handwashing before handling candy reduced SARS-CoV-2 detection to 10%, compared to 60% with unwashed hands. Washing candy with detergent further reduced viral load by 62.1%.
population_specificity: 10 recently diagnosed asymptomatic or mildly/moderately symptomatic COVID-19 patients.
effective_dosage: Not specified (handwashing and ≥1 minute detergent treatment).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the impact of low-cost water, sanitation, and handwashing (WSH) interventions on reducing enteropathogen carriage in young children.
results_summary: WSH interventions were associated with reduced prevalence and quantity of enteric viruses (norovirus, sapovirus, adenovirus 40/41) but showed no significant effect on bacteria, parasites, or cumulative stunting-associated pathogens.
population_specificity: Children aged 14±2 months in rural Bangladesh.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the impact of a handwashing intervention on caregiver knowledge, handwashing behaviors, and disease incidence among children in an orphanage in rural Malawi.
results_summary: The study found significant increases in caregiver hand hygiene knowledge and handwashing with soap, along with observed improvements in child handwashing behaviors. Disease incidence decreased, with acute respiratory infections dropping by 80% and diarrhea by 33% post-intervention.
population_specificity: Children and caregivers in an orphanage in rural Malawi.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the role of handwashing as a counterstrategy to control the COVID-19 pandemic.
results_summary: The study highlights handwashing as a critical measure in combating COVID-19, recommending its continued practice globally until a vaccine or decisive treatment is available. It emphasizes handwashing as part of a "new normal" behavioral change.
population_specificity: General population in various settings (not specified further).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to highlight the critical role of handwashing in preventing communicable diseases, particularly during the COVID-19 pandemic, and advocate for increased investment in water services in underserved regions.
results_summary: The study emphasizes that handwashing is a neglected but essential public health measure, with over 26% of the global population lacking access to handwashing stations at home, rising to over 50% in low-income countries. It argues that affordable, reliable water services are foundational for health, dignity, and development, especially during and after the COVID-19 crisis.
population_specificity: Global population, with a focus on underserved regions and low-income countries.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to discuss the protective role of frequent handwashing in minimizing the risk of spreading COVID-19 infections.
results_summary: The abstract highlights that handwashing is widely recommended by health agencies like the WHO and CDC to reduce the disease burden of COVID-19, suggesting its utility in infection control. However, it does not provide specific data or clinical results on handwashing's effectiveness.
population_specificity: General population (not specified further)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to summarize behavioral strategies for improving handwashing in children and propose a treatment package for teaching handwashing to young children.
results_summary: The review highlights effective behavioral strategies for promoting handwashing in children and identifies gaps for future research, suggesting a comprehensive treatment approach for young children.
population_specificity: Children, specifically young children

study_goal: The researchers aimed to test a scalable intervention to promote handwashing with soap and evaluate its effectiveness in changing handwashing practices.
results_summary: The intervention had minimal effect on increasing handwashing with soap at key times (+2.4%, not statistically significant) but was associated with increased handwashing without soap before food contact (+13%, statistically significant). The low intervention dose may have compromised effectiveness.
population_specificity: Men, women, and children in 14 villages in Cross-River state, Nigeria.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to identify and describe the application of digital technology in hand hygiene research among children in educational settings.
results_summary: The review found that digital technologies (computer games, videos, and video cameras) were effective in hand hygiene studies over short periods, especially when combined with other measures. Future research may explore their role in developing sustainable handwashing behaviors.
population_specificity: Children ≤12 years in educational settings
study_duration: Short temporal periods (exact duration not specified)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine if produce commodity type influences the effectiveness of handwashing with soap and water or a two-step alcohol-based hand sanitizer (ABHS) intervention in reducing soil and bacterial contamination on farmworker hands.
results_summary: The study found that handwashing and two-step ABHS interventions significantly reduced soil and some bacterial loads, but effectiveness varied by produce type (cantaloupe, jalapeño, tomato). Contamination from cantaloupe was harder to remove, and two-step ABHS performed similarly to handwashing.
population_specificity: Farmworkers (n=326) harvesting cantaloupe, jalapeño, and tomato.
effective_dosage: Handwashing with soap and water or two-step ABHS after 30-90 minutes of harvesting.
study_duration: Single intervention session (30-90 minutes of harvesting followed by hand hygiene).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to develop and tailor a scalable handwashing and water treatment intervention (CHoBI7) to reduce diarrheal disease transmission among household members of diarrhea patients in Bangladesh.
results_summary: The modified CHoBI7 intervention was well-received, with participants recognizing its benefits and suggesting improvements for acceptability and feasibility, such as additional pictorial modules and better-quality technologies. Considerations for scalability included local availability of supplies and integration into existing health programs.
population_specificity: Household members of diarrhea patients in Bangladesh, including caregivers and healthcare providers.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of the CHoBI7 program in increasing handwashing with soap among diarrhoea patients and their household members in a healthcare facility setting.
results_summary: The study found that both intervention arms (Health Facility Visit + Soapy Water and Health Facility Visit + Handwashing Station) significantly increased handwashing with soap at key events compared to the standard message arm, with odds ratios of 3.02 and 4.12, respectively.
population_specificity: Diarrhoea patients and their accompanying household members in healthcare facilities in Dhaka, Bangladesh.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to highlight the rare but severe complication of iatrogenic blindness and cerebral infarction following hyaluronic acid injections for cosmetic purposes.
results_summary: The study reported a fatal case of ophthalmic artery embolism, extensive cerebral infarction, and multiple organ failure after HA filler injection, emphasizing the need for awareness and early intervention.
population_specificity: Patients receiving HA injections for cosmetic purposes, specifically in the glabellar and nasolabial fold regions.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare complications of PRP injections versus alternative treatments (including hyaluronic acid) for foot and ankle pathologies.
results_summary: The study found no specific complications attributed to hyaluronic acid, but PRP had higher rates of post-injection pain compared to alternatives (including hyaluronic acid). Only one severe complication (resolved surgically) was reported in the PRP group.
population_specificity: Patients with foot and ankle pathologies (Achilles tendon injuries, plantar fasciitis, ankle osteoarthritis, osteochondral lesions of the talus).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of hyaluronic acid (HA) as a targeting agent in a multifunctional drug delivery system for synergistic antitumor therapy.
results_summary: HA was used to decorate the surface of the drug-loaded nanoparticles, enhancing their targeting ability to cancer cells overexpressing CD44 while reducing toxicity to normal cells. The study demonstrated that HA contributed to the high drug-loading capacity and effective targeting of the nanoparticles.
population_specificity: Cancer cells (in vitro or animal model, not specified for human use).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effect of 2 kDa hyaluronic acid oligosaccharides (HA2k) on reducing facial spots and sagging skin.
results_summary: HA2k treatment reduced facial spots and sagging after 4 weeks in human subjects and inhibited inflammation and UVB-induced damage while promoting autophagy and keratinocyte turnover in vitro.
population_specificity: Human study participants (specific demographics not detailed) and normal human epidermal keratinocytes (NHEK) in vitro.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the efficacy of hyaluronic acid treatment on periodontitis in rats exposed to gamma radiation, assessing radiographic and histopathological outcomes.
results_summary: Hyaluronic acid treatment significantly improved bone density in rats with induced periodontitis, both with and without gamma radiation exposure, and enhanced periodontal tissue healing. The highest bone density was observed in the group treated with hyaluronic acid alone, while the irradiated group showed the lowest density.
population_specificity: Adult male Albino rats with induced periodontitis, some exposed to gamma radiation.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to develop a pH-responsive hyaluronic acid hydrogel loaded with mometasone furoate to improve postoperative care for chronic rhinosinusitis by combining sustained anti-inflammatory drug delivery with hemorrhage control.
results_summary: The hydrogel demonstrated exceptional swelling capacity, sustained drug release (79.4% over 14 days), excellent biocompatibility, and enhanced hemostatic effects via the intrinsic coagulation pathway.
population_specificity: Human nasal epithelial cells (HNEPCs) were used in vitro; the intended application is for patients with chronic rhinosinusitis (CRS) post-surgery.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of hyaluronic acid (HA)-decorated nanocatalysts for targeted tumor therapy, combining photodynamic, chemodynamic, and photothermal therapies.
results_summary: The HA-decorated nanocatalysts enhanced photothermal conversion, ROS generation, and tumor targeting, leading to significant tumor growth inhibition and reduced metastasis in 4T1 cancer cells. The treatment also induced immunogenic cell death and ferroptosis.
population_specificity: 4T1 cancer cells (murine breast cancer model)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the anti-photoaging effects of a composite nano-system (HA-CXO-Lip) containing hyaluronic acid (HA) and chuanxiong oil (CXO) through antioxidant and anti-apoptotic mechanisms.
results_summary: HA-CXO-Lip significantly reduced oxidative stress markers (ROS, 4-HNE, MDA) and restored antioxidant enzyme levels (SOD, GSH-Px, CAT, HYP) in vitro. In vivo, it reduced UVB-induced skin damage, improved collagen arrangement, and inhibited apoptosis via modulation of Bax/Bcl-2 and AKT/mTOR pathways.
population_specificity: In vitro HaCaT cell models and in vivo murine (mouse) photoaging models.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to educate radiologists about the imaging features of injectable fillers, including hyaluronic acid, to avoid misdiagnosis of pathology obscured by filler injections.
results_summary: The study found that hyaluronic acid appears strongly hyperintense in imaging due to its water-like composition and hydrophilic nature, which helps distinguish it from true pathology.
population_specificity: Radiologists and patients receiving hyaluronic acid filler injections.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the clinical improvement of PRP with versus without hyaluronic acid (HA) in treating hip osteoarthritis (HOA).
results_summary: Dual therapy (PRP plus HA) led to significantly higher pain scores at 3 and 12 months compared to PRP alone, indicating worsened pain with HA. No functional score differences were observed between groups at any follow-up.
population_specificity: Patients with hip osteoarthritis (HOA).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the applications of Hyaluronic Acid (HA) in various fields, including wound healing, cancer progression, angiogenesis, and drug delivery systems.
results_summary: The study found that HA plays a crucial role in cell signaling, tissue regeneration, and pathobiology, with significant implications in cancer progression and therapeutic delivery. HA's biocompatibility and physico-chemical properties make it suitable for drug delivery systems and treatments in esthetic medicine, rhinology, and arthrology.
population_specificity: Not specified (general review of HA applications)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to measure objective tissue metrics and patient-reported outcomes of HA fillers in different facial regions over 12 weeks.
results_summary: The study found that HA fillers showed the highest volume maintenance in the midface (79.2%) and the lowest in the lips (37.2%) over 12 weeks, with significant improvements in patient-reported outcomes for facial appearance and psychological/social function.
population_specificity: Females aged 40 to 65.
effective_dosage: Not specified (different HA fillers used for specific facial regions).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether hyaluronic acid, when used in hybrid polymeric protein nanoparticles with silymarin, could enhance stem cell targeting and improve bioavailability for liver fibrosis treatment.
results_summary: The study found that hyaluronic acid-based nanoparticles effectively delivered silymarin, suppressing liver fibrosis markers (Collagen I, TGF-β1, SMAD3, MMP-3) and activating hepatic progenitor stem cells (HNF1β, FOXl1, CD90, Vimentin, CD105) without inducing inflammation.
population_specificity: Mice with CCl4-induced liver fibrosis.
effective_dosage: Not specified for hyaluronic acid alone; silymarin NPs were injected twice weekly.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the clinical safety and efficacy of a high and low molecular weight hyaluronic acid (HA) hybrid complex injection for skin rejuvenation.
results_summary: The study found significant improvements in skin firmness, transepidermal water loss (TEWL), dermis ecodensity, and dermis thickness, with a median GAIS score indicating 51%-75% improvement. No important side effects were observed, and subject satisfaction was moderate.
population_specificity: 20 subjects with wrinkled, dry, or rough skin.
effective_dosage: 2 mL of stabilized high- and low-molecular-weight HA per session, administered twice with a 4-week interval.
study_duration: Two treatment sessions spaced 4 weeks apart.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to develop a stable hyaluronic acid (HA)-conjugated nanocomplex for targeted chemotherapy and photothermal therapy in breast cancer treatment.
results_summary: The HA-conjugated nanocomplex demonstrated high drug encapsulation efficiency (92.8%), appropriate cytotoxicity toward breast cancer cell lines (4T1 and MCF7), and significant tumor growth inhibition in mice when combined with laser treatment.
population_specificity: BALB/c mice bearing breast cancer tumors and in vitro breast cancer cell lines (4T1 and MCF7).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether combining ginseng-derived exosome-like nanoparticles (GENs) with hyaluronic acid (HA)-based hydrogels could improve GENs' stability, retention in tumor tissues, and therapeutic efficacy in breast cancer.
results_summary: The study found that HA-based hydrogels significantly enhanced GENs' uptake by cells, increased tumor apoptosis, improved retention in tumor tissues, and boosted antitumor effects. GENs and GENs@Hydrogels induced apoptosis via the PTEN/PI3K/Akt/mTOR and caspase-dependent pathways and modulated immune responses by downregulating PD-L1 and upregulating MHC-I and CD8+T cells.
population_specificity: Breast cancer (4T1 cell line in vitro and in vivo models)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the efficacy and safety of mesenchymal precursor cells (MPCs) with or without hyaluronic acid (HA) compared to saline control in treating chronic low back pain associated with moderate degenerative disc disease.
results_summary: MPC+HA showed significant pain reduction compared to control, particularly in subjects with chronic low back pain duration less than 68 months, but the primary efficacy endpoint was not met. The treatment was well-tolerated with no serious adverse events related to the procedure or HA.
population_specificity: 404 subjects with chronic low back pain and moderate degenerative disc disease at one level from L1 to S1.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to develop hyaluronic acid (HA) composite hydrogels to modulate the joint microenvironment, achieve controlled drug release, and enhance lubrication for osteoarthritis (OA) treatment.
results_summary: The HA composite hydrogels demonstrated broad ROS scavenging capacity, matrix metalloproteinase-9 responsive drug release, protective efficacy against cartilage matrix degradation, efficient lubrication, and effective OA attenuation in both in vitro and in vivo experiments.
population_specificity: Not specified (in vitro and in vivo models, likely animal studies).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of a novel transdermal drug delivery system combining hyaluronic acid (HA), silver nanoparticles (AgNPs), and insulin (Ins) for treating diabetes-associated wounds.
results_summary: The HAMNs@AgNPs-Ins system demonstrated significant wound healing (89.66% healing rate) and glucose reduction (72.29% reduction at 8h), outperforming the control group (48.19% healing rate). It also showed sustained antibacterial activity and skin safety.
population_specificity: Diabetes mellitus (DM)-associated wound patients

study_goal: The researchers aimed to highlight the risks and complications associated with the use of hyaluronic acid in non-surgical nasal procedures, particularly in the context of subsequent surgical interventions.
results_summary: The abstract notes that hyaluronic acid use in the nose can complicate future surgical manipulation and carries risks if performed by unqualified personnel. No specific efficacy or safety outcomes are detailed.
population_specificity: Individuals seeking non-surgical nasal aesthetic procedures (rhinomodeling).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the efficacy of dissolving microneedle (DMN) patches in enhancing drug delivery and improving clinical outcomes in psoriatic plaques when used with a topical agent (betamethasone and calcipotriol).
results_summary: The DMN patch group showed significantly improved mPASI scores (80.4% improvement) compared to the no-needle patch (64.6%) and ointment-only groups (55.5%). In vitro and ex vivo studies confirmed enhanced drug delivery and micro-channel formation without adverse events.
population_specificity: Patients with mild psoriasis (22 patients, 132 paired lesions).
effective_dosage: Topical agent (betamethasone and calcipotriol) applied once daily.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of hyaluronic acid (HA) as a tumor-targeting component in a multifunctional nanomedicine for synergistic cancer therapy.
results_summary: The study found that HA-loaded Por-COF@TPZ/HA demonstrated enhanced inhibition of cell activity (1.2 times higher than the control group) and achieved high-efficiency chemotherapy by activating TPZ under hypoxia caused by photodynamic therapy. The combined photodynamic-photothermal therapy and chemotherapy showed outstanding synergistic effects.
population_specificity: In vitro and in vivo cancer models (specific type not specified).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of 35 kDa hyaluronan fragment (HA35) injections in managing persistent localized pain in a rheumatoid arthritis patient after conventional treatments failed.
results_summary: HA35 injections significantly improved persistent localized pain, with complete relief in elbow and knee pain and restored joint mobility. Continuous HA35 injections followed by oral HA35 powder also completely relieved foot pain.
population_specificity: 58-year-old Chinese female with rheumatoid arthritis and persistent localized joint pain after conventional treatment.
effective_dosage: Not specified (only mentions "HA35 injections" and "oral HA35 powder").
study_duration: Not specified (only mentions "continuous HA35 injections" followed by oral administration).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to establish expert consensus on the use of hyaluronic acid viscosupplementation for knee osteoarthritis in various clinical scenarios.
results_summary: The expert panel reached consensus on 18 of 30 scenarios, identifying symptom severity, comorbidities, lack of alternatives, and patient refusal of arthroplasty as key factors influencing HA use. Obesity and advanced osteoarthritis were noted as predictors of poor response.
population_specificity: Patients with knee osteoarthritis, assessed by rheumatologists, orthopedic surgeons, and rehabilitation physicians from seven European countries.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to develop a dual-drug loaded hyaluronic acid (HA) nanodrug system for chemo-photothermal synergistic therapy in triple-negative breast cancer.
results_summary: The HA-based nanodrugs demonstrated pH, glutathione, and thermal triple-responsiveness, selectively accumulated in tumors, and achieved a 99.11% tumor inhibition ratio with negligible systemic toxicity. The combination of chemotherapy and photothermal therapy synergistically enhanced anti-tumor efficacy while preventing metastasis and recurrence.
population_specificity: Triple-negative breast cancer model (preclinical study).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to develop a glucose-responsive insulin delivery system using hyaluronic acid conjugated with a diboronate glucose binder to improve precision in insulin therapy.
results_summary: The hyaluronic acid-based insulin formulation corrected blood glucose levels in diabetic mice and demonstrated glucose-responsive function during a glucose challenge, though its functional duration was limited without secondary interactions.
population_specificity: Diabetic mice

study_goal: The researchers aimed to develop a hyaluronic acid-conjugated nanocarrier for targeted co-delivery of hydroxycamptothecin (HCPT) and GLUT1 siRNA to overcome drug resistance in acute myeloid leukemia (AML).
results_summary: The hyaluronic acid-conjugated nanocarrier effectively targeted CD44 receptors on AML cells, improving cellular uptake and synergistically inhibiting DNA synthesis by downregulating glycolysis and P-glycoprotein expression. Both in vitro and in vivo experiments demonstrated strong antitumor efficacy and excellent biosafety.
population_specificity: Acute myeloid leukemia (AML) cells and models.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the clinical effects of intraarticular hyaluronic acid (HA) injection versus leukocyte-poor platelet-rich plasma (LP-PRP) in adult patients with knee osteoarthritis.
results_summary: The study found that HA was less effective than LP-PRP in improving WOMAC total scores, physical function scores, VAS scores, and IKDC scores at 6- and 12-month follow-ups. However, there was no significant difference in adverse events between the two treatments.
population_specificity: Adult patients with knee osteoarthritis.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to develop and evaluate a hyaluronic acid-based hydrogel system (OcuPairTM) for sealing and stabilizing traumatic corneal injuries in a battlefield setting.
results_summary: The hyaluronic acid-based adhesive hydrogel effectively sealed full-thickness corneal wounds in a rabbit model, demonstrated mechanical robustness, and showed no toxicity over 30 days with favorable clinical outcomes for 5 days.
population_specificity: Rabbit corneal injury model (preclinical study).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the therapeutic potential of dexamethasone-loaded hyaluronic acid nanoparticles (ADHA NPs) in alleviating dry eye syndrome by assessing their anti-inflammatory, mucoadhesive, and drug retention properties.
results_summary: ADHA NPs demonstrated high drug release (94.99% at 6h), enhanced water retention (86.89%), significant anti-inflammatory effects, and improved tear production in a dry eye model. The formulation also showed cytocompatibility and maintained cell integrity in human corneal epithelial cells.
population_specificity: Human corneal epithelial cells (HCECs) and LPS-induced RAW 264.7 cell lines, with in vivo components.
study_duration: In vivo drug retention was observed up to 12h.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the clinical indications, post-operative complications, and dosimetric impact of stabilized hyaluronic acid (sHA) spacer insertion in the retroperitoneum for stereotactic body radiation therapy (SBRT) of retroperitoneal cancers.
results_summary: Spacer insertion significantly improved PTV coverage and reduced bowel radiation exposure, with no post-operative complications observed. The technique enabled higher target doses while maintaining safe OAR limits.
population_specificity: Two cases of retroperitoneal lesions (primary left renal cell carcinoma and oligometastatic renal cell carcinoma in the right adrenal gland).
effective_dosage: 42 Gy in three fractions (renal lesion) and 40 Gy in five fractions (adrenal lesion).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the wound healing and antimicrobial potential of a formulation containing hyaluronic acid, a polysaccharide extract from Cerioporus squamosus, and dexpanthenol.
results_summary: The three-component formulation, including hyaluronic acid, achieved 35.81% wound closure in vitro and demonstrated significant antimicrobial activity against skin pathogens.
