Gene expression analysis indicated upregulation of VEGF and collagen, suggesting enhanced wound healing at the molecular level.
population_specificity: HaCaT keratinocytes (in vitro) and an animal model (in vivo).
effective_dosage: Not specified for hyaluronic acid alone.
study_duration: Not specified for hyaluronic acid alone.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the efficacy and safety of cross-linked high-molecular-weight hyaluronic acid (DIART ONE 90 mg in 3 mL) in patients with knee osteoarthritis.
results_summary: The study found statistically significant improvements in clinical, functional, and psychological scores at 3 and 6 months, with reduced benefits at 12 months. No significant side effects were reported except for injection site pain.
population_specificity: Patients aged 18-65 years with mild-moderate knee osteoarthritis.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the histopathological effects and VEGF expression in uterine tissue following treatment with hyaluronic acid, alone and in combination with methylprednisolone, in a rat model of Asherman Syndrome.
results_summary: Hyaluronic acid treatment increased uterine lumen diameter and vascularization. Combined treatment with methylprednisolone significantly reduced fibrosis and inflammation while increasing gland counts and VEGF expression compared to either treatment alone.
population_specificity: Female Sprague-Dawley rats with experimentally induced Asherman Syndrome.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the potential of Hyaluronic Acid-based nanoparticles as a biocompatible, targeted, and multifunctional platform for improving cancer treatment efficacy while reducing systemic toxicity.
results_summary: The study found that HA-based nanoparticles enhance cellular uptake, improve pharmacokinetics, and increase tumor localization, leading to better anticancer efficacy with reduced toxicity. They also enable therapeutic combinations, such as co-delivery of chemotherapeutics with gene therapies, and integration of photothermal and photodynamic therapies.
population_specificity: Preclinical studies (not specified for human populations).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether methacrylated hyaluronic acid (HA) combined with silk fibroin (SF) could serve as an effective biomaterial for nerve conduits, promoting nerve regeneration.
results_summary: SF-HA nanofibers demonstrated superior alignment, mechanical properties, and biocompatibility compared to HA alone, enhancing Schwann cell attachment, proliferation, and neurite extension in dorsal root ganglia neurons.
population_specificity: In vitro study using human Schwann cells and dorsal root ganglia neurons.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the 2-year outcomes of using cross-linked hyaluronic acid (HA) in combination with modified coronally advanced tunnel (MCAT) and subepithelial connective tissue graft (SCTG) for treating multiple gingival recessions.
results_summary: The study found no significant difference in mean root coverage between the test (MCAT + SCTG + HA) and control (MCAT + SCTG) groups after 2 years, with both showing around 90% complete root coverage. However, HA significantly improved soft tissue texture compared to the control group, though the clinical relevance of this difference may be minimal.
population_specificity: 24 patients with multiple gingival recessions.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the efficacy of a novel, less-rigidly crosslinked, 15 mg/mL resilient hyaluronic acid filler for improving radial cheek lines.
results_summary: The study found significant improvements in radial cheek lines using the Allergan Fine Lines Scale and quality-of-life questionnaires, with notable differences between baseline and follow-up measurements at 4 and 8 weeks. The treatment enhanced skin appearance and potentially improved patient self-assurance.
population_specificity: Twenty subjects with radial cheek lines.
effective_dosage: 15 mg/mL hyaluronic acid filler, two treatments 4-6 weeks apart.
study_duration: 8 weeks (4 weeks after the last treatment).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of a hyaluronic acid-based hydrogel as a delivery system for multi-stage immuno-chemo synergistic therapy in postoperative colorectal cancer treatment and metastasis prevention.
results_summary: The hyaluronic acid-based hydrogel demonstrated strong tissue adhesion, sustained drug release for over 20 days, and achieved 100% survival without recurrence in treated mice, while also inhibiting peritoneal metastasis and eradicating intraperitoneal tumors within 20 days.
population_specificity: Mice with postoperative colorectal cancer.
study_duration: Up to 80 days for survival monitoring, with tumor eradication observed within 20 days.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to develop and evaluate HA-functionalized carrier-free nanoparticles for enhanced chemo/photodynamic therapy in cancer treatment.
results_summary: HA@H-T nanoparticles demonstrated high cellular uptake (87.4%), high ROS production (90.5%), and enhanced tumor suppression in 4T1, A549, and HCT116 cells, with improved combined chemo/photodynamic therapy in vivo.
population_specificity: In vitro (4T1, A549, HCT116 cells) and in vivo animal models.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the role of circCDR1 and TMZ nanoparticles (CNPs) in inhibiting glioma progression and their potential therapeutic effects.
results_summary: The study found that circCDR1 regulates the miR-890/GJB6 axis to inhibit glioma progression, and CNPs co-delivering TMZ and circCDR1 showed superior inhibitory effects on glioma cell progression and tumor growth compared to TMZ alone or other NPs.
population_specificity: Glioma tissues and cells

study_goal: The researchers aimed to report a case of vestibular dysfunction following hyaluronic acid injection into the ear and explore the underlying mechanism of this complication.
results_summary: The study found that hyaluronic acid injection into the ear led to acute unilateral vestibular disease in a patient, with symptoms including nausea, vomiting, and gait instability. The complication was attributed to hyaluronic acid accumulation in the mastoid region, entering the inner ear and causing vestibular dysfunction.
population_specificity: A 39-year-old woman receiving hyaluronic acid injection in the ear.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of hyaluronic acid-based hydrogels, particularly when combined with bioactive materials like chitosan and collagen, in treating chronic skin wounds such as diabetic foot ulcers.
results_summary: The study found that HA-based hydrogels, especially when combined with chitosan and collagen, improved mechanical strength, degradation rates, and antibacterial/anti-inflammatory properties, making them highly suitable for wound healing. Responsive hydrogel dressings were also developed to adapt to diabetic wound microenvironments, enabling targeted drug release.
population_specificity: Patients with chronic skin wounds, specifically diabetic foot ulcers.

study_goal: To describe and characterize the mechanism of action of intra-articular hyaluronic acid (IAHA) products concerning nociception, chondroprotection, and anti-inflammatory properties.
results_summary: IAHA demonstrated chondroprotective effects by increasing anabolic biomarkers and reducing catabolic biomarkers, reduced inflammatory mediators, enhanced proteoglycan and glycosaminoglycan synthesis, improved mechanical function, and significantly decreased knee pain.
population_specificity: Patients with knee osteoarthritis (OA).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the lubricating effectiveness of Hyaluronic Acid (HA) supplementation versus platelet-rich plasma (PRP) inflammation suppression in treating temporomandibular disorders (TMDs).
results_summary: HA statistically significantly improved lubrication in the temporomandibular joint (TMJ) compared to PRP, as demonstrated in a two-arm trial with 39 patients per group. The study suggests HA supplementation is more effective for TMD treatment.
population_specificity: Patients with temporomandibular disorders (TMDs).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to develop an ex vivo human skin model to evaluate the local biological effects of subcutaneously injected biomacromolecules, including hyaluronic acid hydrogel.
results_summary: The study demonstrated that the ex vivo human skin model could visualize changes in extracellular matrix proteins (e.g., type I and III procollagens, elastin) after hyaluronic acid injection, but semi-quantitative analysis showed high variability due to skin heterogeneity. Absolute quantitative methods (e.g., RT-qPCR, ELISA) were suggested for better biomarker reporting.
population_specificity: Ex vivo full-thickness human skin samples.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the clinical effectiveness of pericapsular injection of polinucleotides (PN) and hyaluronic acid (HA) in improving pain and mandibular kinematics in patients with TMJ osteoarthrosis.
results_summary: The study found that pericapsular injection of PN and HA significantly reduced pain (VAS score) and improved mandibular kinematics compared to physiotherapeutic exercises, though maximum opening improvement was not statistically significant.
population_specificity: 60 patients suffering from temporomandibular joint (TMJ) osteoarthrosis.

study_goal: To evaluate the impact of oral intake of Hyaluronic Acid (HA) on skin health across different age groups and skin types.
results_summary: Oral HA significantly improved skin hydration after 2-8 weeks, enhanced skin tone after 4-8 weeks, and increased epidermal thickness after 12 weeks in both young and elderly participants.
population_specificity: 129 female participants, including young and elderly groups with different skin types.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the validity of mixing hyaluronic acid (HA) with platelet-rich plasma (PRP) for injectable treatment of temporomandibular joint (TMJ) disorders.
results_summary: The study found that HA supplementation with PRP provided a mean advantage in TMJ disorder treatment, with improved articular pain and mandibular mobility compared to HA or PRP alone. The meta-analysis included six studies, showing a significant benefit at the 6-month follow-up.
population_specificity: Patients with temporomandibular joint disorders (TMDs).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the efficacy and safety of combining arthroscopic surgery with hyaluronic acid for treating meniscal injuries compared to arthroscopic surgery alone.
results_summary: The study found that combining arthroscopic surgery with hyaluronic acid improved treatment efficiency, reduced joint pain, and enhanced joint function and mobility without increasing complications. The combined approach demonstrated superior efficacy compared to surgery alone.
population_specificity: 955 patients with meniscal injuries (473 in the combined treatment group, 482 in the surgery-alone group).

study_goal: To evaluate the effectiveness of a full-spectrum hyaluronan (FS-HA) food supplement in improving skin aging parameters in adult females.
results_summary: After 28 days, subjects taking FS-HA showed significant improvements in skin hydration (+10.6%), wrinkle depth (-18.8%), wrinkle volume (-17.6%), elasticity, and firmness (+5.1%), confirmed by both instrumental measurements and self-assessment questionnaires.
population_specificity: Sixty adult females with mild-to-moderate skin aging signs.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the clinical outcomes of intra-articular injections of Hyaluronic Acid versus Platelet-Rich Plasma in treating knee osteoarthritis.
results_summary: Both Hyaluronic Acid and Platelet-Rich Plasma improved knee symptoms and functional status for up to 18 months, but Platelet-Rich Plasma provided longer-lasting relief and required fewer re-injections over 36 months.
population_specificity: 200 patients with symptomatic knee osteoarthritis (Kellgren-Lawrence grade 2 or 3).
effective_dosage: 3 intra-articular injections, 2 weeks apart (specific dosage not mentioned).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the physiological and therapeutic role of high molecular weight hyaluronic acid (HMW-HA) in pregnancy, focusing on its involvement in processes like implantation, immune response, and cervical remodeling.
results_summary: The study found that HMW-HA plays a critical role in supporting physiological pregnancy by promoting blastocyst adhesion, preventing miscarriage, and reducing pre-term birth risks. Evidence suggests HMW-HA supplementation could be beneficial in pregnancy.
population_specificity: Pregnant individuals (gestational models, including in-vitro, in-vivo, ex-vivo, and clinical studies).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate whether intra-articular hyaluronic acid (HA) injections combined with arthrocentesis are more effective than other medications for improving temporomandibular disorder (TMD) symptoms and to assess HA's impact on patients' quality of life.
results_summary: HA injections, with or without arthrocentesis, showed benefits in improving TMD symptoms and quality of life, but the literature review did not establish HA as superior to other treatments due to varied etiologies, treatment methods, and conflicting results.
population_specificity: Patients with temporomandibular disorders (TMD).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the efficacy and safety of MSCs versus hyaluronic acid in treating osteoarthritis (OA).
results_summary: The study found that while hyaluronic acid showed limited improvement in OA symptoms at 6 months, MSCs demonstrated significant symptom relief after 12 months. No serious adverse effects were reported for either treatment.
population_specificity: Elderly individuals with osteoarthritis.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the safety and efficacy of a novel HA injection device (Dermashine balance) for improving skin hydration and elasticity.
results_summary: The study found that HA injections significantly improved skin hydration compared to placebo, but no significant difference was observed in skin elasticity. No severe adverse events were reported.
population_specificity: 60 participants in a single-center randomized double-blinded parallel-group clinical study.
effective_dosage: HA injections administered three times across the face (specific dosage not mentioned).
study_duration: 12 weeks (measurements taken at 4, 8, and 12 weeks post-treatment).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of a nutritional intervention (hydrolyzed eggshell membrane) compared to placebo on the appearance of hair, skin, and nails in healthy middle-aged adults.
results_summary: The study found significant improvements in facial skin appearance (crow's feet and skin tone), hair thickness, reduction in hair breakage, and hair growth at 4, 8, and 12 weeks. No subjective improvements were observed for nails.
population_specificity: Healthy middle-aged adults

study_goal: The study does not address Hyaluronic Acid; it explores the effect of vitamin D supplementation on cardiovascular risk factors in PCOS patients with NAFLD.
results_summary: The study does not report findings on Hyaluronic Acid; it focuses on vitamin D's potential effects on liver biochemistry and cardiovascular risk factors in PCOS patients.
population_specificity: Women with polycystic ovary syndrome (PCOS) and non-alcoholic fatty liver disease (NAFLD).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the mechanistic behavior of Hyaluronic Acid (HA) in biological synthesis and degradation, as well as its applications in various formulations for physiological conditions.
results_summary: The study highlights HA's versatility in formulations like fillers, creams, and nanocarriers, emphasizing its biocompatibility, mucoadhesion, and potential in tissue regeneration, anti-aging, and anti-inflammatory applications. It also notes improved cellular uptake and sustained release when HA is encapsulated in nanocarriers.
population_specificity: Not specified (review article)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of a gel compound containing hyaluronic acid (E-Gastryal®) in managing laryngopharyngeal reflux (LPR) as part of new therapeutic strategies.
results_summary: The study highlighted promising outcomes from large Italian surveys in outpatient settings, suggesting that the hyaluronic acid-containing gel may be effective in managing LPR symptoms, though specific efficacy details were not detailed in the abstract.
population_specificity: Patients with laryngopharyngeal reflux (LPR) in outpatient clinics.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the efficacy of hyaluronic acid vaginal gel therapy versus topical vaginal estrogens in treating de novo dyspareunia in women using hormonal oral contraceptives.
results_summary: Hyaluronic acid significantly improved dyspareunia, sexual function, and vaginal atrophy, though it was less effective than estriol gel. Both treatments enhanced sexuality, but estriol showed superior results in reducing dyspareunia and improving vaginal maturation.
population_specificity: Sexually active women using hormonal oral contraceptives and experiencing de novo dyspareunia.
effective_dosage: Hyaluronic acid vaginal gel once a day.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the efficacy of intra-articular injections of polynucleotides (Condrotide) in pain relief and functional improvement for knee osteoarthritis or grade III/IV chondropathy.
results_summary: The study found significant improvement in KOOS scores, reduced NRS pain, and improved range of motion after 60 days, suggesting short- to medium-term symptom and functional benefits.
population_specificity: 95 subjects (33 men, 62 women) aged 53-80 with knee osteoarthritis or grade III/IV chondropathy.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether immediate supplementation with Hyaluronic Acid (HA) after knee arthroscopy improves short-term analgesic and functional outcomes.
results_summary: The study found no statistical difference in pain scores (VAS), WOMAC, or Tegner-Lysholm scores between HA and bupivacaine groups at any time point, concluding no benefit of HA injection post-arthroscopy within the first 6 weeks.
population_specificity: 98 patients undergoing routine knee arthroscopy at a tertiary referral center.
effective_dosage: 3 mL of HA administered once post-surgery.
study_duration: Follow-up assessments up to 6 weeks post-intervention.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the efficacy and safety of recombinant human lubricin versus 0.18% sodium hyaluronate (HA) eye drops in treating moderate dry eye disease (DED).
results_summary: HA showed improvement in some dry eye symptoms but was significantly outperformed by lubricin in reducing foreign body sensation, burning/stinging, pain, sticky feeling, blurred vision, and photophobia, as well as in fluorescein staining, TFBUT, and erythema. No treatment-related adverse events were reported for HA.
population_specificity: Subjects with moderate dry eye disease (DEWS Grade 2-3), aged 51.9 ± 11.8 years (lubricin group) and 61.8 ± 13.3 years (HA group).
effective_dosage: 0.18% sodium hyaluronate eye drops, administered BID for 7 days, then as needed (2-6 drops per eye) for 7 days.
study_duration: 14 days total (7 days BID, 7 days as needed).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate hyaluronic acid as a potential urinary proteomic marker for detecting bladder cancer, comparing its sensitivity and specificity to traditional methods like cystoscopy and cytology.
results_summary: The abstract mentions hyaluronic acid as one of several urinary proteomic markers under investigation for bladder cancer detection, noting that some markers show higher sensitivity but lower specificity than cytology. However, no proteomic marker, including hyaluronic acid, has yet replaced cystoscopy for definitive diagnosis.
population_specificity: Patients undergoing surveillance for bladder cancer (specific demographics not detailed).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to understand the biosynthesis of 3,4-dihydroisocoumarins in Hydrangea serrata and how elicitors like aluminium chloride affect their production.
results_summary: The study found that aluminium chloride treatment upregulated genes related to terpene and triterpenoid synthesis in roots but did not enhance 3,4-dihydroisocoumarin levels. Organ-specific accumulation patterns of hydrangenol, phyllodulcin, and their glycosides were identified.
population_specificity: Hydrangea serrata leaves and roots (plant-based study, no human subjects).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of Hydrangea serrata leaf extract (WHS) and hydrangenol on hair growth, anti-inflammatory, and anti-androgenic properties using cell cultures, mice, and human skin organoid models.
results_summary: WHS and hydrangenol enhanced 5α-reductase inhibition, stimulated dermal papilla cell growth, increased keratin and ceramide synthase gene expression, and reduced inflammatory and androgen signaling markers. Oral WHS administration in mice and human skin organoids confirmed hair growth-promoting effects.
population_specificity: C57BL/6 mice and human skin organoid models.

study_goal: To develop a bioadhesive, injectable hyaluronic acid-based hydrogel that supports chondrogenesis and reduces cell invasion from bone marrow under joint mechanical loading.
results_summary: HA-Tyr hydrogels demonstrated good mechanoresilience and induced TGF-β1 activation, supporting chondrogenic graft maturation without exogenous growth factors. The hydrogels functioned as effective cell carriers with low cell invasion.
population_specificity: Human bone marrow-derived mesenchymal stromal/stem cells (in vitro study).
effective_dosage: Various concentrations of hydrogen peroxide (H2O2) for crosslinking (specific amounts not detailed).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the lipid metabolic effects of Hydrangea serrata hot water leaf extract (WHS) on adipogenesis and its potential to regulate obesity-related risk factors.
results_summary: WHS treatment suppressed glycerolipid elevation, including TG and DG, and prevented a shift toward long-chain unsaturated fatty acids. It also stabilized key lipid markers associated with obesity, suggesting potential for reducing obesity-related risks.
population_specificity: 3T3-L1 cells (in vitro study)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the anti-colitic effects and molecular mechanisms of hydrangenol, a bioactive compound from Hydrangea serrata, in a DSS-induced mouse colitis model.
results_summary: Hydrangenol significantly alleviated colitis symptoms, reduced macrophage infiltration, preserved colonic epithelial integrity, and suppressed pro-inflammatory mediators through NF-κB, AP-1, and STAT1/3 inactivation.
population_specificity: DSS-induced colitis mice, HT-29 colonic epithelial cells, and LPS-induced RAW264.7 macrophages.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the anti-adipogenic and anti-obesity effects of Hydrangea serrata water extract (WHS) and its underlying molecular mechanisms in preadipocytes and obese mice.
results_summary: WHS reduced adipogenic gene expression, inhibited preadipocyte proliferation, and alleviated obesity-related outcomes in mice, including body weight gain, fat accumulation, and liver steatosis. It also modulated gut microbiota and activated thermogenic proteins in brown adipose tissue.
population_specificity: Genetically obese db/db mice and 3T3-L1 preadipocytes.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the potential antiobesity effects of Hydrangea Serrata as a natural alternative to current antiobesity drugs.
results_summary: The abstract mentions a previously reported antiobesity effect of Hydrangea Serrata, suggesting it may help alleviate obesity, but specific results are not detailed.
population_specificity: Not specified in the abstract.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the efficacy and safety of hydroquinone 2% cream versus T. chebula 5% cream in treating melasma.
results_summary: Hydroquinone 2% cream showed statistically significant reduction in mMASI scores by weeks 8 and 12, but had higher frequencies of side effects like skin irritation compared to T. chebula. No significant differences in efficacy were found between the two treatments at any time point.
population_specificity: Patients with facial melasma.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether geranyl hydroquinone (GHQ) could alleviate pain hypersensitivity in rheumatoid arthritis by targeting neutrophil accumulation, N1 polarization, and ROS production.
results_summary: GHQ reversed N1 polarization and ROS production in synovial neutrophils from RA patients in vitro and alleviated pain hypersensitivity in a CIA mouse model. It also demonstrated superior therapeutic effects compared to methotrexate.
population_specificity: Rheumatoid arthritis patients (synovial fluid samples) and collagen-induced arthritis (CIA) mice.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the efficacy and safety of hydroquinone-containing creams (generic TCC and TRI-LUMA) in Chinese patients with moderate-to-severe melasma.
results_summary: The generic TCC showed 52.2% efficacy, comparable to TRI-LUMA (57.1%), with no significant difference in adverse effects (69.6% vs. 90.5%). The placebo group had no adverse events.
population_specificity: Chinese patients with moderate-to-severe melasma.
effective_dosage: Once daily application (specific concentration not mentioned).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the efficacy of 4% hydroquinone with ectoine cream versus 5% cysteamine with ectoine cream in treating melasma.
results_summary: The study found that 4% hydroquinone with ectoine cream effectively improved melasma pigmentation and quality of life, with results comparable to 5% cysteamine, though the difference between the two treatments was not statistically significant.
population_specificity: Patients with melasma across three hospitals in Indonesia.
effective_dosage: 4% hydroquinone with ectoine cream (frequency not specified).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the catalytic performance of hydroquinone-treated Cu(I/II)-HKUST-1 in the copper-catalyzed azide-alkyne cycloaddition (CuAAC) reaction.
results_summary: The study found that hydroquinone-treated Cu(I/II)-HKUST-1 exhibited exceptional structural integrity and superior catalytic performance in the CuAAC reaction between phenylacetylene and benzyl azide, highlighting its potential as an effective heterogeneous catalyst.
population_specificity: Not applicable (in vitro catalytic study).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to develop an electrochemical sensor for the simultaneous detection of catechol and hydroquinone in environmental samples.
results_summary: The study demonstrated that the sensor effectively detected hydroquinone with a detection limit of 0.28 μM in a concentration range of 0.5-50 μM, showing high catalytic efficiency and practical applicability in real water samples.
population_specificity: Environmental water samples

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the structure-reactivity relationships in the sorption and oxidative degradation of hydroquinone on Mn-oxide surfaces.
results_summary: Cryptomelane showed higher sorption and oxidation capacity for hydroquinone compared to HMO. Hydroquinone exhibited lower reactivity than catechol, with less Mn reduction and dissolution from Mn-oxides. Structural changes in Mn-oxides occurred due to reactions with hydroquinone, including Mn(IV) reduction and formation of Mn(III) and Mn(II).
population_specificity: Environmental systems (Mn-oxide-rich soils and wastewater treatment systems)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the tyrosinase inhibitory and antioxidant potency of hydroquinone-like diphenols derived from kojic acid for potential use in treating hyperpigmentation and skin disorders.
results_summary: The study found that hydroquinone-like diphenols, particularly the α-naphthol derivative (6i), exhibited significantly higher tyrosinase inhibitory and antioxidant activity compared to kojic acid, with 6i also effectively reducing melanin content in melanoma cells.
population_specificity: In vitro enzymatic assays and melanoma (B16F10) cells.
effective_dosage: IC50 values provided (e.g., 0.14-3.7 µM for tyrosinase inhibition, 10.1 µM for antioxidant activity).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether combining exercise, metformin, and tert-butyl hydroquinone (tBHQ) could counteract mitochondrial damage in the liver of obese middle-aged female rats.
results_summary: The triple-treatment approach improved mitochondrial function by increasing ATP synthesis, OXPHOS complex activities, and membrane potential while reducing ROS production. It also enhanced AMPK and PGC1α expression and promoted animal survival.
population_specificity: Obese middle-aged female rats fed a high-fat diet.
effective_dosage: tBHQ administered at 10 mg/kg/day for 7 days/month.
study_duration: From 10 to 15 months of age (5 months total).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the tolerability and efficacy of a combined dermo-cosmetic product (10% nicotinamide, 5% magnesium ascorbyl phosphate, and 5% hyaluronic acid) versus 4% hydroquinone for treating melasma.
results_summary: Both treatments improved melasma severity and quality of life, with no significant differences between them at 14 and 60 days, though hydroquinone showed greater reduction in colorimetric luminosity at 60 days. The combined product was safe and well-tolerated but numerically less effective than hydroquinone.
population_specificity: Women with facial melasma.
effective_dosage: 4% hydroquinone applied at night (placebo in the morning).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the impact of Hydroquinone, a benzene metabolite, on trophoblast function, specifically its effects on migration and invasion via the AhR pathway.
results_summary: Hydroquinone impaired trophoblast migration and invasion by activating the AhR pathway, reducing Twist1 and IFITM1 expression. IFITM1 overexpression rescued the impaired migration, suggesting the AhR-Twist1-IFITM1 axis is critical in trophoblast function.
population_specificity: First-trimester trophoblast cells (Sw.71)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether human umbilical cord MSC-originated exosomes (HUC-MSC-exo) could protect human bronchial epithelial cells (16HBE) from damage caused by Hydroquinone (HQ) and explore the underlying mechanism involving the miR-221/PTEN axis.
results_summary: The study found that HUC-MSC-exo alleviated HQ-induced cytotoxic, oxidative stress, and genotoxic damage in 16HBE cells by modulating the miR-221/PTEN pathway, reducing oxidative stress, and promoting cell proliferation and migration.
population_specificity: Human bronchial epithelial cells (16HBE) in vitro.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to report a rare case of diffuse facial leukoderma resulting from localized hydroquinone use, despite its common application for hyperpigmentation.
results_summary: The study found that hydroquinone, while commonly used for hyperpigmentation, can cause adverse effects like leukoderma, which in this case was diffuse despite localized application. The leukoderma responded to vitiligo treatment algorithms when addressed promptly.
population_specificity: Case report of an individual with hyperpigmentation treated with hydroquinone.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the efficacy of combining plasma rich in growth factors (PRGF) with topical 4% hydroquinone (HQ) versus using topical 4% HQ alone for treating dermal-type melasma.
results_summary: Both treatments significantly improved melasma, with combination therapy showing slightly better results (40.38% improvement vs. 33.42% for monotherapy), though the difference was not statistically significant. Patients reported higher satisfaction with the combination therapy.
population_specificity: Twenty female patients with dermal-type melasma.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine how hydroquinone (HQ) affects the biosynthesis of arbutin and 6'-O-caffeoylarbutin (CA) in Vaccinium dunalianum suspension cells.
results_summary: HQ significantly enhanced arbutin synthesis, peaking at 15.52 ± 0.28 mg·g-1 after 0.5 mmol·L-1 HQ treatment for 12 h. Metabolomics and transcriptomics revealed upregulation of key genes and metabolites linked to arbutin and CA synthesis.
population_specificity: Vaccinium dunalianum suspension cells (in vitro study).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to develop and evaluate the effectiveness of N,S-codoped activated carbon-ZIF-67 (NSAC-ZIF-67@C) as an adsorbent for removing Hydroquinone (HQ) from wastewater.
results_summary: The synthesized NSAC-ZIF-67@C demonstrated a high adsorption capacity of 962 mg·g-1 for HQ, maintained performance over 5 cycles, and followed pseudo-second-order kinetics and the Freundlich isotherm model. Adsorption mechanisms included pore filling, electrostatic attraction, π-π interaction, and hydrogen bonding.
population_specificity: Not applicable (in vitro study on wastewater treatment).
effective_dosage: Not applicable (adsorption capacity measured in mg·g-1).
study_duration: Not specified (study focused on adsorption behavior under varying conditions).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effectiveness and safety of topical 3% tranexamic acid (TA) versus 4% hydroquinone (HQ) for treating melasma.
results_summary: The study found that 4% HQ significantly reduced melasma severity (measured by mMASI scores) over 8 weeks, with no statistically significant difference in efficacy compared to 3% TA. Both treatments showed comparable safety, though HQ had more side effects.
population_specificity: Indonesian population with melasma.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the antiplatelet effects of ortho-carbonyl hydroquinones, particularly their impact on mitochondrial function in platelets.
results_summary: The study found that linking triphenylphosphonium cation to a bicyclic ortho-carbonyl hydroquinone moiety enhanced antiplatelet effects by disrupting mitochondrial function, including uncoupling OXPHOS, increasing mitochondrial ROS production, and reducing membrane potential and OCR. These effects were dependent on the complete compound structure.
population_specificity: Not specified (likely in vitro or animal model based on abstract).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the efficacy of cysteamine 5% cream versus hydroquinone 4%/ascorbic acid 3% cream in treating postinflammatory hyperpigmentation (PIH) caused by acne.
results_summary: Both hydroquinone/ascorbic acid and cysteamine creams significantly reduced PIH severity and melanin index, with no significant difference in efficacy between the two treatments. Quality of life improved significantly only with cysteamine, though no significant difference was observed between the groups.
population_specificity: Patients with acne-induced postinflammatory hyperpigmentation.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the efficacy and safety of a hydroquinone-free serum (ABT) versus 4% hydroquinone (HQ) in treating moderate to severe hyperpigmentation, including melasma.
results_summary: ABT showed comparable efficacy to 4% HQ, improving hyperpigmentation, skin tone evenness, and melasma severity, with high patient satisfaction (≥89%). Both treatments were well tolerated, with no significant safety concerns reported.
population_specificity: 113 subjects (44 with melasma) of diverse racial/ethnic backgrounds: Asian (22%), Black/African American (27%), Hispanic (22%), and White/Caucasian (28%).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the molecular mechanism of hydroquinone (HQ)-induced leukemic cell malignant proliferation and identify potential therapeutic targets for chronic lymphocytic leukemia (CLL).
results_summary: The study found that Linc01588 deletion inhibited malignant biological characteristics of HQ-induced leukemic cells via the miR-9-5p/SIRT1 pathway, suggesting a potential therapeutic target for CLL. HQ-induced leukemic transformation corresponded to CLL, with Linc01588 playing a key role in cell viability, apoptosis, and TNF-α secretion.
population_specificity: TK6 cells (human lymphoblastoid cell line) and nude mice inoculated with malignant TK6 cells, with additional validation in human CLL cell line MEC-2.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether combining Danggui Shaoyao powder (DSP) with Hydroquinone (H) was more effective than Hydroquinone alone in treating melasma.
results_summary: The study found that combining DSP with Hydroquinone significantly reduced MASI scores more than Hydroquinone alone, with a 77.26% reduction in the DSP + H group compared to 64.31% in the H group after 12 weeks. Patient recovery and satisfaction were also higher in the DSP + H group.
population_specificity: 40 melasma patients over 18 years old.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the tolerability and efficacy of sequential clobetasol/hydroquinone (CLOB-HQ) versus isolated hydroquinone (HQ) for treating melasma.
results_summary: Both CLOB-HQ and HQ showed progressive improvement in melasma severity, quality of life, and aesthetic outcomes, with no significant difference between the two treatments. No severe side effects were reported, and the sequential regimen was deemed safe and well tolerated.
population_specificity: 50 women with facial melasma.
effective_dosage: 4% hydroquinone applied nightly for 60 days (HQ group) or after 14 days of 0.05% clobetasol (CLOB-HQ group).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness and safety of hydroquinone (HQ) as a treatment for hyperpigmentation disorders such as melasma, post-inflammatory hyperpigmentation, and solar lentigines.
results_summary: The study found that HQ is effective in treating hyperpigmentation disorders and can be combined with other therapies for enhanced results, though it has side effects and should be prescribed by trained professionals.
population_specificity: Individuals with hyperpigmentation disorders (e.g., melasma, post-inflammatory hyperpigmentation, solar lentigines).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the role of cardiolipin in hydroquinone-induced mitochondrial dysfunction and cell death in retinal pigmented epithelial cells.
results_summary: Hydroquinone caused mitochondrial oxidative stress, dysfunction, and protective mitophagy initially, but prolonged exposure led to pyroptotic cell death via cardiolipin-mediated pathways. Cardiolipin-targeting antioxidants mitigated these effects.
population_specificity: ARPE-19 cell line (retinal pigmented epithelium model)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the effectiveness of photo rejuvenation combined with tranexamic acid and hydroquinone cream in treating complex facial pigmentation.
results_summary: The study found that the combination treatment significantly improved effectiveness (98.15% vs 83.33%), reduced melasma severity (1.58 vs 2.96), and enhanced skin elasticity and water content compared to hydroquinone and tranexamic acid alone.
population_specificity: 108 patients with complex facial pigmentation.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the role of hydroquinone derivatives in mitochondrial regulation and their potential as antiplatelet agents.
results_summary: The study suggests that hydroquinone derivatives may exert antiplatelet activity by targeting mitochondrial function, which is essential for platelet activation. The review highlights the potential of these compounds in developing new antiplatelet drugs.
population_specificity: Not specified (general focus on platelet activation in diseases like cancer, diabetes, Alzheimer's, and cardiovascular conditions).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the efficacy and safety of hydroquinone versus azelaic acid in treating melasma.
results_summary: Hydroquinone showed a higher mean change in melasma severity (MASI) compared to azelaic acid, but no significant differences were observed in objective response scale, pigmentation reduction, or adverse events. There was a trend toward better responses with azelaic acid, though not statistically significant.
population_specificity: 673 patients with melasma.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to isolate and evaluate the antihyperglycemic and anti-type 2 diabetic activities of marine hydroquinone (zonarol) from brown algae extract.
results_summary: Zonarol showed strong inhibitory activity against α-glucosidase and α-amylase, significantly reduced postprandial glycemia, rejuvenated pancreatic islet cells, and improved glucose metabolism in diabetic mice. It also elevated levels of SCFAs linked to glucose homeostasis.
population_specificity: STZ-induced diabetic mice.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to establish quantitative methods for determining zonarol in biological samples and investigate its basic pharmacokinetics after oral or intravenous administration in mice.
results_summary: Zonarol was detected dose-dependently in biological samples, with an absolute bioavailability of 25.0%. It showed higher and slower distribution in the brain compared to the liver and kidney, suggesting potential for cerebral disease treatment.
population_specificity: Experimentally induced mice models.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of molecularly imprinted Zr-doped TiO2 photocatalysts in degrading hydroquinone (HQ) as a pollutant.
results_summary: The study found that MIP-ZrO2-TiO2 achieved a 90.58% degradation rate of HQ under UV irradiation, outperforming non-imprinted catalysts. Zr doping and molecular imprinting enhanced TiO2's photocatalytic activity for HQ degradation.
population_specificity: Not applicable (in vitro study on pollutant degradation).
effective_dosage: 10 mg/L HQ concentration, 1 g/L catalyst dose.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the molecular mechanism by which hydroquinone (HQ) induces acute myeloid leukemia (AML), focusing on the role of circRNA hsa_circ_401351 in HQ-TK6 cell proliferation and apoptosis.
results_summary: The study found that HQ exposure reduced hsa_circ_401351 expression, which was linked to increased cell proliferation and reduced apoptosis. Treatment with inhibitors (5-AzaC or TSA) restored hsa_circ_401351 expression, slowing proliferation and enhancing apoptosis in HQ-TK6 cells.
population_specificity: TK6 cells (a human lymphoblastoid cell line) malignantly transformed by HQ exposure.
effective_dosage: 10.0 μmol/L HQ for malignant transformation; 5 μmol/L 5-AzaC or 200 nmol/L TSA for treatment.
study_duration: 24 hours for inhibitor treatments (5-AzaC and TSA).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine how hydroquinone affects the self-renewal and proliferation of preleukemic hematopoietic cells and identify the underlying molecular pathway.
results_summary: Hydroquinone significantly increased colony formation in preleukemic bone marrow cells by activating the Ppar-γ pathway, and this effect was reversed by a Ppar-γ inhibitor (GW9662). The findings suggest hydroquinone promotes malignant proliferation in preleukemic cells.
population_specificity: Preleukemic bone marrow cells derived from transgenic mice carrying the Mll-Af9 fusion gene.
